titleStmt.title:
A Paraphrase on the Seven
Penitential PSALMS, by the
Reverend Mr. R---d D---l, D. of A.
Or Strephon to Belinda.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: HEAR, fair Belinda, hear thy Suppliant's cry,
I faint──── oh! hear and pardon e're I die;
Wild and Distracted with thy Love I flee
Thou Lovely Charmer of my Soul to thee,
I know my follies must thy anger move
Chastise me────── but Chastise me in thy Love,
Oh! let thy wonted softness take my part
Vex'd are my Bones and broken────── is my Heart,
My Rivals, See, exulting in their Pride
Watch for my ruin, and my fate deride,
Must they in human cruel Triumph have
Is there no Hope, no Refuge, but the Grave.
Why heaves my swelling Heart with sorrows prest
Why do's it pant, and flutter in my Breast,
What would'st thou say my Heart, or how express
How tell the piteous Tale of thy Distress,
Be hush't fond thing, and let thy Sighs alone
Too well thy Follies, and thy Griefs are known,
She knows, she knows thee all, she sees thee through,
Ah! as she sees, wou'd she but pity too.
Oh! hear me, kind Belinda, and forgive
Heal, heal a broken Heart and bid me rise and live;
Alass how chang'd────── all Comeliness is fled
No Sprightly Ardour plays around my Head,
Deep Eating Care has Furrow'd up my Face
Unhappy Strephon is not──── what he was,
Ah endless source of woe; ah fatal smart
Which inward Burns and preys upon my Heart,
What should I do; my easy Couch I prest
And thought that gentle Sleep would give me rest,
Sleep would not, could not come, the silent Night
Enlarg'd my woes, and gave them all to sight,
From side to side I turn'd, I rav'd I tost
And wish'd my very sense of being lost;
Thus pierc'd with grief, and wilder'd with despair
The Nightingale laments her tender care,
To every wind her sorrow is addrest
When some rude hand has robb'd her downy Nest,
She trys the brake, she Searches all the plain
Often she's heard to call but call in vain,
She hangs her Wings, she hates the tedious Day
And pensive mourns the live long Night away;
Oh hear me, save me, pity and forgive
Nor is it yet too late to bid me live,
One kind reviving Word will set me free
Belinda let me live, that I may live for thee;
Come, fair Belinda, take thy Servants part
Come fair Belinda, Triumph o're my Heart,
Seise, take it all, and let the wand'rer be
Close knit in sweetest bonds to Love and Thee,
Come, fair Belinda, take my injur'd part
Oh come, and reign for ever in my Heart;
The Boy, th' ambitious Boy comes thund'ring on
And with his powerful Darts do's hunt me down,
Come quickly to my aid, thou welcome Guest
And gently lull my fainting Soul to rest,
Oh haste thee, do not stop, make no delay
How pressing is my danger, haste away;
She hears, she hears, go bear the Tidings round
My joyful Heart springs forward to the Sound;
She heard, she saw, and willing to forgive
She pitied, nay she kindly bid me live,
Then, then I felt a sudden transport rise
Spring in my Heart, and lighten in my Eyes,
From my Charm'd Soul I banish'd every care,
All Heaven rush'd in, and took possession there.
